content.title: Business Cycles
content.definition: Business cycles are the recurring fluctuations in aggregate economic activity consisting of expansions and contractions that occur around a long-run growth trend. A complete cycle has four phases: (1) expansion - rising output, employment, and incomes; (2) peak - the high point before decline; (3) contraction/recession - falling output, rising unemployment; (4) trough - the low point before recovery. The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) officially dates US business cycles. Cycles are irregular in duration (typically 2-10 years) and amplitude, driven by shifts in aggregate demand, supply shocks, financial crises, and policy changes.

definitions_glossary.business_cycle: Recurring pattern of expansion and contraction in aggregate economic activity around a growth trend
definitions_glossary.expansion: Phase of rising real GDP, falling unemployment, increasing investment and consumption - typically 6-10 years
definitions_glossary.recession: Period of declining real GDP - officially two consecutive quarters of negative growth (common rule) or NBER determination
definitions_glossary.peak: Turning point from expansion to contraction - maximum economic activity before decline begins
definitions_glossary.trough: Turning point from contraction to expansion - minimum economic activity before recovery begins
definitions_glossary.recovery: Initial expansion phase after trough - economy climbing back toward previous peak
definitions_glossary.output_gap: Difference between actual GDP and potential GDP: (Y - Y*)/Y* - positive in boom, negative in recession
definitions_glossary.leading_indicators: Variables that predict future economic activity: stock prices, building permits, yield curve, consumer confidence
definitions_glossary.lagging_indicators: Variables that confirm past trends: unemployment rate (peaks after recession ends), inflation
definitions_glossary.coincident_indicators: Variables moving with current economy: industrial production, personal income, employment
definitions_glossary.nber: National Bureau of Economic Research - official arbiter of US recession dates based on comprehensive analysis
definitions_glossary.potential_gdp: Y* = maximum sustainable output at full employment - actual GDP fluctuates around this trend
definitions_glossary.stabilization_policy: Fiscal and monetary policy aimed at smoothing business cycle fluctuations - reducing amplitude

key_points: Business cycles are recurring but irregular fluctuations in aggregate economic activity around growth trend
Four phases: Expansion → Peak → Contraction (Recession) → Trough → Expansion
US average: Expansions ~6-10 years, recessions ~11 months since WWII (1945-2020)
NBER definition: 'Significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting more than a few months'
Not strictly 'two negative quarters' - NBER considers employment, production, income, sales
Causes: Demand shocks (consumer confidence, investment collapse), supply shocks (oil, pandemic), financial crises, policy errors
Leading indicators: Stock market, yield curve (inverted predicts recession), building permits, consumer expectations
Procyclical variables: Employment, investment, consumption, industrial production move with cycle
Countercyclical variables: Unemployment, bankruptcies move opposite to cycle
Policy response: Central banks cut rates in recession, raise in boom; fiscal policy expands/contracts

examples.title: Great Recession (2007-2009)
examples.description: Triggered by housing bubble burst and financial crisis. Peak: December 2007. Trough: June 2009. Duration: 18 months (longest since Great Depression). GDP fell 4.3%, unemployment rose from 5% to 10%. Caused by: housing crash → mortgage defaults → bank failures → credit freeze → demand collapse. Recovery: slowest post-war, took until 2014 to regain employment levels. Demonstrated financial system's role in amplifying cycles.
examples.context: Severe recession driven by financial crisis
examples.data: Duration: 18 months (Dec 2007 - June 2009). GDP: -4.3%. Unemployment: 5% → 10%. Recovery: 6+ years to pre-recession employment

examples.title: COVID-19 Recession (2020)
examples.description: Shortest recession in US history: Peak February 2020, Trough April 2020 - only 2 months! But deepest: GDP fell 31% annualized in Q2. Unusual cause: government-mandated lockdowns and pandemic fear, not typical demand/financial shock. Sharp V-shaped recovery due to massive fiscal stimulus ($5T+), Fed support, and vaccine development. Unemployment: 3.5% → 14.7% → 6% within one year.
examples.context: Pandemic-induced recession with unprecedented policy response
examples.data: Duration: 2 months (Feb-Apr 2020). GDP Q2 2020: -31% annualized. Unemployment: 3.5% → 14.7% (April) → 6% (2021)

examples.title: Post-War US Expansion (1991-2001)
examples.description: Longest expansion in US history (at the time): 120 months. Followed 1990-91 recession. Driven by: technology boom (internet), productivity growth, globalization, low inflation allowing easy monetary policy. Ended with dotcom bubble burst (2000) and 9/11 attacks. Showed cycles can be long but eventually end. Succeeded by shorter 2001 recession (8 months).
examples.data: Duration: 120 months (March 1991 - March 2001). Growth: 4%/year average. Unemployment fell to 4%. Record length until 2020

examples.title: 2020-2024 Expansion
examples.description: Began April 2020 after COVID trough. Rapid initial recovery (5.7% growth in 2021). Unusual features: inflation surge (supply chains + demand), labor market tightness despite short recession, Fed tightening cycle. As of late 2024, no recession despite rate hikes - 'soft landing' debate. Illustrates modern challenge: balancing inflation fighting against recession risk.
examples.context: Current cycle with inflation and policy tightening
examples.data: Expansion since April 2020. GDP 2021: +5.7%, 2022: +2.1%, 2023: +2.5%. Inflation: peaked 9.1% (June 2022). Unemployment: 3.5-4%

examples.title: Yield Curve Inversion as Leading Indicator
examples.description: Inverted yield curve (short rates > long rates) has preceded every US recession since 1970. Inversion in 2019, then recession in 2020 (though COVID was proximate cause). Inversion in 2022-23, recession predictions... but no recession yet. Mechanism: Inverted curve suggests market expects Fed cuts (weak economy), signals reduced lending profitability. About 12-18 month lead time historically.
examples.context: Using leading indicator to predict recessions
examples.data: 10Y-2Y yield inverted before: 1980, 1989, 2000, 2006, 2019, 2022 recessions. Lead time: 12-18 months typically

content.statement: Business cycles represent the recurring pattern of expansion and contraction in aggregate economic activity that characterizes market economies. Understanding the phases, causes, indicators, and policy responses to business cycles is essential for macroeconomic analysis, forecasting, and stabilization policy.

explanation.intuition: Think of the economy like breathing - it naturally expands and contracts. During expansion (inhale), businesses hire more, consumers spend more, investment rises, optimism spreads. Eventually, the economy reaches a peak and can't sustain the pace - maybe prices rise too fast, debts become unsustainable, or a shock hits. Then contraction (exhale): spending falls, businesses cut back, unemployment rises, pessimism spreads. At the trough, the economy is depleted but conditions are set for recovery - low prices attract buyers, pent-up demand builds, and the cycle begins again. The goal of stabilization policy is to make the breathing more gentle - avoiding deep contractions and overheating expansions.
explanation.key_insight: The crucial insight is that business cycles are partly self-reinforcing through expectations and financial mechanisms. In expansion: optimism → more spending → more income → more optimism. Rising asset prices → more borrowing capacity → more investment → higher prices. This can overshoot sustainable levels (bubble). In contraction: pessimism → less spending → falling income → more pessimism. Falling asset prices → tighter credit → less investment → lower prices. This can undershoot (depression). Policy aims to moderate these feedback loops: central bank raises rates in boom (cool expectations), cuts in recession (boost confidence). Understanding what triggers turning points - often financial imbalances, external shocks, or policy errors - is key to forecasting.
explanation.technical_details: NBER Business Cycle Dating Committee examines: real personal income less transfers, nonfarm payroll employment, household survey employment, real personal consumption expenditures, wholesale-retail sales, industrial production. Recession declared when 'significant decline in economic activity spread across economy, visible in production, employment, income, lasting more than few months.' Output gap: (Y - Y*)/Y* where Y* is potential GDP (estimated via production function or statistical filters). Okun's Law: 1 percentage point unemployment above natural rate ≈ 2% output gap. Cycle theories: Keynesian (demand fluctuations, animal spirits), Real Business Cycle (technology shocks), Financial (Minsky, credit cycles), New Keynesian (sticky prices + shocks).

mathematical_formulation.output_gap: (Y - Y*)/Y* where Y* is potential GDP estimated from trend
mathematical_formulation.okuns_law: (Y - Y*)/Y* ≈ -2(u - uⁿ) where uⁿ is natural rate of unemployment
mathematical_formulation.trend_cycle_decomposition: Y_t = Trend_t + Cycle_t (Hodrick-Prescott filter commonly used)
mathematical_formulation.leading_indicator_index: Composite of: average weekly hours, unemployment claims, new orders, building permits, stock prices, interest rate spread, consumer expectations
mathematical_formulation.recession_probability: Probit models using yield curve slope, leading indicators to estimate P(recession in next 12 months)

keynesian.cause: Fluctuations in aggregate demand, driven by 'animal spirits' (investment volatility) and multiplier effects
keynesian.mechanism: Sticky prices prevent instant market clearing → quantity adjustments → unemployment
keynesian.policy: Active fiscal and monetary policy to stabilize demand

real_business_cycle.cause: Technology shocks (productivity changes) cause efficient responses by workers and firms
real_business_cycle.mechanism: Positive shock → higher productivity → more work → more output. Negative shock opposite
real_business_cycle.policy: Cycles are efficient responses - policy intervention may be harmful

financial_cycle.cause: Credit booms and busts (Minsky): stability breeds instability as leverage builds
financial_cycle.mechanism: Credit expansion → asset bubbles → crash → deleveraging → recession
financial_cycle.policy: Macroprudential regulation, lender of last resort, financial stability monitoring

new_keynesian.cause: Demand and supply shocks in presence of nominal rigidities (sticky prices/wages)
new_keynesian.mechanism: Shocks + sticky prices → output gaps → gradual adjustment
new_keynesian.policy: Monetary policy following Taylor Rule, fiscal stabilizers

concepts: Statistics: Leading indicator models, recession probability
Political business cycles: Electoral timing of expansions
Policy credibility: Central bank independence and stabilization
Economic voting: Incumbents punished for recessions

verified_claims.claim: Yield curve inversion preceded every US recession since 1970
verified_claims.derivation: FRED data: 10Y-2Y spread inverted before recessions of 1980, 1981-82, 1990-91, 2001, 2007-09, 2020. No false negatives ✓

verified_claims.claim: Okun's Law: 1pp unemployment above natural rate ≈ 2% output gap
verified_claims.derivation: Okun (1962) original estimate; modern estimates range 1.5-2.5. 2:1 is standard approximation ✓

verified_claims.claim: Post-WWII US expansions average ~6-10 years, recessions ~11 months
verified_claims.derivation: NBER: Average expansion 65 months (1945-2020), average contraction 11 months. Recent expansions longer ✓
